thread.title: McCoy commits to play at Louisina Tech
thread.title_full: McCoy commits to play at Louisina Tech

title: McCoy commits to play at Louisina Tech
text:
Jaiden McCoy commits to play basketball at Louisiana Tech Chris Thomas 10:55 PM, Oct 18, 2015 2 hours ago Previous Next 
Jaiden McCoy had already made up her mind about her college basketball recruitment when she met with Tyler Summitt during an official visit to Louisiana Tech on Sunday in Ruston, La. 
"Is it a yes?" said Summitt, a Knoxville native and the Lady Techsters women's basketball coach. 
McCoy, a 6-foot-3 center from Farragut High School, didn't answer immediately, determined to make Summitt sweat out her intentions. 
"I paused just long enough to leave him hanging," McCoy said with a chuckle, "then I said â€˜Yes.' He started jumping around." 
McCoy made her commitment to Louisiana Tech public on her Twitter account late Sunday, hours after returning from her official visit. She chose the Lady Techsters over scholarship offers from Middle Tennessee State, Virginia Tech and San Diego State. 
The move didn't come as a surprise. She told the News Sentinel on Sept. 24 she was leaning "heavily" toward playing for Summitt, the son of legendary Tennessee women's basketball coach Pat Summitt. 
"We knew about two weeks (ago) we were going to commit this weekend. We planned on it," McCoy said. "It was a big decision, and Tyler's the best, honestly. Making the decision to go there and play for him was easy. And the campus is beautiful." 
Tyler Summitt played high school basketball at Webb before walking on at Tennessee in 2010. He was hired in 2014 at Louisiana Tech, which has won three national championships and reached 13 Final Fours. He coached McCoy in a fall league during her sixth grade year in 2009. 
McCoy, known for her prowess as a shot blocker, earned second-team All-PrepXtra honors as a junior, averaging 12.1 points, 8.2 rebounds and 3.4 blocks to help Farragut reach a Class AAA state sectional. 
"Louisiana Tech is a great fit for her," Farragut girls basketball coach Jason Mayfield said. ""Her size and athleticism combined will translate great to the college level. To be 6-3 and move like she does, that's a big asset and one that's hard to find at the high school level." 
Chris Thomas covers high school sports. Follow him at twitter.com/prepxtra. Copyright 2015 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.
